dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, big news coming out about Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce giant. Um, they're having another IPO, right? This time in New York.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, big news coming out about Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce giant. Um, they're having another I P O, right? This time in New York.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the worlds biggest IPO so far this year, Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba is set to raise up to $12.9 billion in a landmark public listing in Hong Kong, boosting the financial markets of a city gripped by political unrest and recession.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's right. And the headline, I gotta say, Host_A, it was a little… wild. Like, 'Record-Breaking IPO Fuels Global Warming, Recession in New York' – then says 'booming economy.' I was like, wait, what?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's right. And the headline, I gotta say, Host_A, it was a little... wild. Like, 'Record-Breaking I P O Fuels Global Warming, Recession in New York' - then says 'booming economy.' I was like, wait, what?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A

dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Very confusing. But the actual numbers are, uh, pretty massive. They're looking to raise what, up to twelve point nine billion dollars?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The price means that Alibaba is set to raise at least $11.3 billion, and up to $12.9 billion if a greenshoe option to list more shares is exercised...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. I mean, that's a *huge* amount of money. But here's the thing that really threw me, they're calling this a secondary listing, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. I mean, that's a huge amount of money. But here's the thing that really threw me, they're calling this a secondary listing, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The debut on the Hong Kong stock exchange is a secondary listing for Alibaba, which initially went public on the New York Stock Exchange in 2014...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it is. And get this, their original Hong Kong listing back in 2014, which raised like, $25 billion? That was apparently, quote, 'the world's smallest IPO in history.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it is. And get this, their original Hong Kong listing back in twenty fourteen, which raised like, twenty five billion dollars? That was apparently, quote, 'the world's smallest I P O in history.'
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The debut on the Hong Kong stock exchange is a secondary listing for Alibaba, which initially went public on the New York Stock Exchange in 2014, raising $25 billion in the worlds biggest IPO in history.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The *smallest*? What?! [laughs] I'm sorry, $25 billion is the smallest IPO in history? That just doesn't compute, Host_A. Like, my mind is blown.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The smallest? What?! I'm sorry, twenty five billion dollars is the smallest I P O in history? That just doesn't compute, Host_A. Like, my mind is blown.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? And this new one, at 'only' $12.9 billion, is being called the 'smallest IPO so far in 2019.' It's like they're leaning into the irony.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? And this new one, at 'only' twelve point nine billion dollars, is being called the 'smallest I P O so far in twenty nineteen.' It's like they're leaning into the irony.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It would also be the worlds biggest IPO so far in 2019: Alibabas Hong Kong listing exceeds Ubers $8.1 billion public debut in New York and AB InBevs $5 billion IPO of its Asia business in Hong Kong earlier this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. I mean, when you think about it, Uber's debut was $8.1 billion, AB InBev's was five billion, and those were considered massive. So, for Alibaba to be the 'smallest,' it's just… wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. I mean, when you think about it, Uber's debut was eight point one billion dollars, A B InBev's was five billion, and those were considered massive. So, for Alibaba to be the 'smallest,' it's just... wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alibabas Hong Kong listing exceeds Ubers $8.1 billion public debut in New York and AB InBevs $5 billion IPO of its Asia business in Hong Kong earlier this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It is wild. And, um, it even says that Saudi Aramco's upcoming IPO, which is expected to hit over $25 billion, could actually break Alibaba's *existing* record for the world's smallest IPO. It's like a competition for who can be the 'smallest' while raising the most.

And, um, it even says that Saudi Aramco's upcoming I P O, which is expected to hit over twenty five billion dollars, could actually break Alibaba's existing record for the world's smallest I P O. It's like a competition for who can be the 'smallest' while raising the most.

dialogue_turns.text: Oh, my gosh. That's, that's hilarious. But putting the ironic labeling aside, why are they doing this New York listing now, you know?

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the worlds biggest IPO so far this year, Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba is set to raise up to $12.9 billion in a landmark public listing in Hong Kong...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, it seems like a few things. You've got the ongoing U.S.-China trade war, and, um, Hong Kong's financial markets have been, like, experiencing some contraction after all the pro-government protests.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, it seems like a few things. You've got the ongoing U S - China trade war, and, um, Hong Kong's financial markets have been, like, experiencing some contraction after all the pro-government protests.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alibabas listing will help boost Hong Kongs financial markets, given that the city recently slid into recession for the first time in over a decade, following more than five months of anti-government protests.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, it's kind of a move away from Hong Kong, potentially dismantling its role as a major IPO venue for Chinese companies, which is a big deal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it's kind of a move away from Hong Kong, potentially dismantling its role as a major I P O venue for Chinese companies, which is a big deal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Alibabas listing helps cement the Hong Kong Stock Exchange as one of this years largest venues for IPOsand that could set an example for other Chinese unicorns to opt for Hong Kong over the U.S. when they go public.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly. And even with all that money, CNBC was reporting some 'dwindling demand' for shares. So, like, they opened their books earlier than expected.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. And even with all that money, C N B C was reporting some 'dwindling demand' for shares. So, like, they opened their books earlier than expected.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...the skyrocketing demand for shares caused Alibaba to close its books earlier than expected, according to CNBC.

dialogue_turns.text: Huh. Interesting. But speaking of massive numbers, we can't talk about Alibaba without mentioning Singles Day, right?

dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. Their eleventh Singles Day just broke records again. $38.4 billion in sales in 24 hours. Just, [overlaps] mind-boggling.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. Their eleventh Singles Day just broke records again. thirty eight point four billion dollars in sales in twenty four hours. Just, mind-boggling.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In its eleventh edition of Singles Day, the biggest shopping event in the world, Alibaba set a new sales record of $38.4 billion in gross merchandise volume during the 24-hour shopping bonanza.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] It's insane! But then you look at, like, Black Friday, Cyber Monday, Amazon Prime Day combined, and Singles Day still, uh, it lags behind those, which is kind of surprising when you put it in perspective.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's insane! But then you look at, like, Black Friday, Cyber Monday, Amazon Prime Day combined, and Singles Day still, uh, it lags behind those, which is kind of surprising when you put it in perspective.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To compare, Singles Day far outpaces other big e-commerce days in the U.S., with Alibabas haul more than double the amount sold on last years Black Friday, Cyber Monday and Amazon Prime Day combined.

dialogue_turns.text: It does, it does. But still, what a powerhouse. They're just, like, constantly reshaping the global e-commerce landscape.
